Engineering Chemistry.text:
üìò COURSE CODE: 100109
üìó Subject: Engineering Chemistry

üìö UNIT 1.0 ‚Äì Atomic and Molecular Structure (8 hrs)
Electromagnetic radiations, Dual nature of electron and Heisenberg uncertainty Principle. Photoelectric effect, Planck's theory. Principles for the combination of atomic orbitals to form a molecular diagram of molecular orbitals. Bent's rule, VSEPR theory (typical example), co-ordination numbers and geometries. Isomerism in transition metal compounds. Metal Carbonyls; Synthesis and Structure.

üìö UNIT 2.0 ‚Äì Spectroscopy (6 hrs)
Principle of rotational and vibrational spectroscopy, selection rule for application in diatomic molecules, elementary idea of electronic spectroscopy, UV-VIS spectroscopy with related rules and its applications. Basic Principle of nuclear Magnetic resonance spectroscopy with applications.

üìö UNIT 3.0 ‚Äì Electrochemistry and Fuels (6 hrs)
Nernst equation, EMF and electrochemical cell, the introduction of corrosion, corrosion mechanism, types of corrosion, water line corrosion, stress corrosion, pitting corrosion, Lead acid storage cell, leclanche cell. Calorific value of fuels, proximate and ultimate analysis of coals, fuel cells, Bio fuels.

üìö UNIT 4.0 ‚Äì Water Chemistry (8 hrs)
Hardness of water, estimation of water hardness by EDTA and Alkalinity method. Removal of the hardness of water- soda lime process, zeolite process, Ion exchange process, Boiler problem, sludge, and scale formation, priming and foaming, Boiler corrosion, and Caustic embrittlement.

üìö UNIT 5.0 ‚Äì Polymer and Plastics (8 hrs)
Polymerization techniques (free radical, ionic, and co-ordination mechanism). Preparation, properties, and technical application of phenol-formaldehyde resins, elastomers, synthetic rubbers (Buna-S, Buna-N, neoprene). Inorganic polymers, Silicones, adhesives, epoxy resins. The structural difference between thermoplastic and thermosetting plastics, the importance of commercially important thermoplastics and thermosets: Polyethylene, Polyvinyl chloride, Polystyrene.

üìö UNIT 6.0 ‚Äì Organic Reactions and Synthesis of A Drug Molecule (6 hrs)
Introduction to intermediates and reactions involving Substitution, Addition, Elimination, Oxidation-Reduction. Diels‚ÄìAlder cyclization and epoxide ring opening reactions, synthesis of commonly used drug molecules like Aspirin.

üìò TEXT / REFERENCE BOOKS:
1. Engineering Chemistry ‚Äì Jain & Jain (Dhanpat Rai)
2. A Textbook of Engineering Chemistry ‚Äì S.S. Dara & S.S. Umare (S. Chand)
3. Engineering Chemistry ‚Äì Wiley India Editorial Team
4. Organic Chemistry ‚Äì Morrison and Boyd
5. Inorganic Chemistry ‚Äì J.D. Lee
6. Engineering Chemistry ‚Äì O.P. Mishra (Asia Publishing House)

Engineering Mathematics-I.text:
üìò COURSE CODE: 100102
üìó Subject: Engineering Mathematics-I

üìö UNIT 1.0 ‚Äì Linear Algebra-I (7 hrs)
Elementary Row operations, Gauss-Jordan Method for finding the inverse of Matrix, Complex Matrix: Hermitian, Skew Hermitian and Unitary Matrix, Vector space, Sub Spaces, Linear dependence and Independences of Vectors, Linear Span, Basis, Dimension, Extension of basis of subspace, The rank of a matrix, Row and column space, Solvability of system of linear equations.

üìö UNIT 2.0 ‚Äì Linear Algebra-II (7 hrs)
Linear Transformations, Kernel and Range of linear transformation, Matrix Representation of a linear transformation, Rank-Nullity Theorem, Eigen Value and Eigen Vectors, Properties of Eigen vectors, Eigen Bases, Orthogonal Transformation, Similarity Transformation, Matrix Diagonalization, Cayley-Hamilton Theorem.

üìö UNIT 3.0 ‚Äì Calculus for Single Variable (7 hrs)
Indeterminate form, L'Hospital Rule, Rolle's Theorem, Mean Value Theorem, Expansion of function (single variable), Taylor and Maclaurin Series, Riemann Integration, Riemann Sum, Improper Integrals, Beta and Gamma function and their properties.

üìö UNIT 4.0 ‚Äì Multivariable Calculus (Differentiation) (7 hrs)
Function with two or more variable, Limit, continuity and Partial differentiation, Total Differentiation, Taylor's and Maclaurin's series for function with two variables, Jacobian, Maxima and Minima, Method of Lagrange's multiplier.

üìö UNIT 5.0 ‚Äì Multivariable Calculus (Integration) (7 hrs)
Double Integral, change of order of integration, Triple integral, Change of Variable in a Double and Triple Integrals, Change to polar coordinate, Change to cylindrical coordinate, Change to spherical polar coordinate, Application to area and volume using double and triple integral.

üìö UNIT 6.0 ‚Äì Vector Calculus (7 hrs)
Scalar and vector fields, Gradient, Directional derivative, Divergence, Curl and their properties, Line integral, Green's theorem in plane (without proof), Surface integral, Stoke's theorem (without proof), Volume Integral, Gauss-Divergence theorem (without proof).

üìò TEXT / REFERENCE BOOKS:
1. Mathematics-I ‚Äì Reena Garg, Khanna Book Publishing, ISBN: 9391505171
2. Advanced Engineering Mathematics ‚Äì Chandrika Prasad & Reena Garg, ISBN: 9789386173522
3. Higher Engineering Mathematics ‚Äì B.V. Ramana, Tata McGraw Hill, ISBN: 9780070634190
4. Advanced Engineering Mathematics ‚Äì S.R.K. Iyengar, R.K. Jain, Narosa, ISBN: 9788184875607
5. Advanced Engineering Mathematics ‚Äì Erwin Kreyszig, 9th Ed., John Wiley & Sons, 2006

English (Communication Skills).text:
üìò COURSE CODE: 100108
üìó Subject: English (Communication Skills)

üìö UNIT 1.0 ‚Äì Vocabulary Building (7 hrs)
Nature of Word Formation; Root Word and Morpheme; Prefix and Suffix; Foreign Expressions in English; Synonym and Antonym; Homophone and Homograph; Abbreviation and Acronym.

üìö UNIT 2.0 ‚Äì Basic Writing Skills (7 hrs)
Parts of Speech: Types of Words; Structures of Sentence; Kind of Sentence; Phrase and Clause; Punctuation Marks; Capitalization; Tenses: Present, Past and Future; Voices: Active and Passive; Formation of Questions using Primary Auxiliaries, Modals and Wh-Words.

üìö UNIT 3.0 ‚Äì Common Errors in English (7 hrs)
Articles; Prepositions; Modifiers; Subject-Verb Agreement; Noun-Pronoun agreement; Redundancies; Cliches; Spelling Error.

üìö UNIT 4.0 ‚Äì Principles of Appropriate Writing (7 hrs)
Defining: Describing, Classifying and Exemplifying; Introduction, Body, and Conclusion; References, Quotations and Illustrations; Organizing the Paragraphs in a Document; 7Cs of the Professional Writing: Clear, Concise, Concrete, Correct, Coherent, Complete and Courteous.

üìö UNIT 5.0 ‚Äì Practices of Formal Writing (7 hrs)
Formal Letter: Cover-Letter and Application; Resume Writing; Report Writing; Minutes of Meeting; Memorandum; Notice; Essay Writing: Personal and Impersonal; Email Writing Etiquettes; Article Writing; Writing for Current Social Media.

üìö UNIT 6.0 ‚Äì Comprehension of Written English (7 hrs)
*Of Studies* (Essay) by Sir Francis Bacon; *The Sun Rising* (Poem) by John Donne; *The Last Leaf* (Story) by O. Henry; Unseen/Untaught Passage.

üìò TEXT / REFERENCE BOOKS:
1. Technical Communication ‚Äì Rizvi, McGraw Hill
2. High School English Grammar and Composition ‚Äì Wren and Martin
3. Contemporary English Grammar ‚Äì J.D. O‚ÄôConnor
4. Word Power Made Easy ‚Äì Norman Lewis
5. English Vocabulary in Use ‚Äì Michael McCarthy and Felicity O'Dell

Engineering Drawing.text:
üìò COURSE CODE: 100104
üìó Subject: Engineering Drawing

üìö UNIT 1.0 ‚Äì Introduction to Engineering Drawing (7 hrs)
Principles of Engineering Graphics and Their Significance, Usage of Drawing Instruments, Lettering, Conic Sections including the Rectangular Hyperbola (General Method Only); Cycloid, Epicycloid, Hypocycloid and Involute; Scales: Plain, Diagonal and Vernier Scales.

üìö UNIT 2.0 ‚Äì Orthographic Projections (7 hrs)
Principles of Orthographic Projections - Conventions - Projections of Points and Lines Inclined to Both Planes; Projections of Planes Inclined Planes; Auxiliary Planes.

üìö UNIT 3.0 ‚Äì Projections of Regular Solids (7 hrs)
Types of Solids, Projections of Solids (Prism, Pyramids, Cone, and Cylinder) Inclined to Both the Planes ‚Äì Auxiliary Views; Draw Simple Annotation, Dimensioning and Scale.

üìö UNIT 4.0 ‚Äì Sections and Sectional Views of Right Angular Solids (7 hrs)
Section of Solids (Prism, Cylinder, Pyramid, Cone), Auxiliary Views; Development of Surfaces of Right Regular Solids ‚Äì Prism, Pyramid, Cylinder and Cone; Draw the Sectional Orthographic Views of Geometrical Solids, Objects From Industry and Dwellings (Foundation to Slab Only).

üìö UNIT 5.0 ‚Äì Isometric Projections (7 hrs)
Isometric Views, Compound Solids; Principles of Isometric Projection, Isometric Scale, Conventions; Isometric Views of Lines, Planes, Simple Solids and Conversion of Isometric Views to Orthographic Views and Vice-Versa.

üìö UNIT 6.0 ‚Äì Overview of Computer Graphics (7 hrs)
Listing the Computer Technologies that Impact Graphical Communication; Theory of CAD Software [Such As: The Menu System, Toolbars (Standard, Object Properties, Draw, Modify and Dimension), Drawing Area (Background, Crosshairs, Coordinate System), Dialog Boxes and Windows, Shortcut Menus (Button Bars), The Command Line, The Status Bar, Different Methods of Zoom], Selecting and Erasing Objects; Isometric Views of Lines, Planes, Simple and Compound Solids.

üìò TEXT / REFERENCE BOOKS:
1. Engineering Drawing ‚Äì N.D. Bhatt, Charotar Publishing House, 53rd Edition, ISBN: 978-9380358277
2. A Textbook of Engineering Drawing ‚Äì R.K. Dhawan, S. Chand Publishing, Revised Edition, ISBN: 978-8121929571
3. Engineering Drawing and Graphics ‚Äì K. Venugopal, V. Prabhu Raja, New Age International Publishers, 3rd Edition, ISBN: 978-8122430120
4. Engineering Graphics with AutoCAD ‚Äì D.M. Kulkarni, A.P. Rastogi, A.K. Sarkar, PHI Learning Pvt. Ltd., 1st Edition, ISBN: 978-8120337834

Innovation Project.text:
üìò COURSE CODE: 100109P
üìó Subject: Innovation Project

üìö COURSE OBJECTIVES:

(a) Encouraging creativity and innovation: Foster a culture of creativity and innovation among engineering students through brainstorming sessions, design thinking exercises, and hands-on projects.

(b) Enhancing problem-solving skills: Provide training on root cause analysis, critical thinking, and decision-making. Equip students to identify, analyze, and solve complex real-world problems.

(c) Developing project management skills: Teach project planning, scheduling, budgeting, and risk management. Promote effective resource management, communication, and collaboration.

(d) Promoting interdisciplinary collaboration: Encourage students from different engineering disciplines to work together on innovative projects to foster teamwork and diverse perspectives.

(e) Facilitating practical application of engineering concepts: Enable students to apply theoretical knowledge to real-world projects, prototypes, or simulations and gain hands-on experience.

üìö PRE-REQUISITE: Nil

üìö COURSE OUTCOMES:

1Ô∏è‚É£ Developed innovative projects: Students will create projects demonstrating creativity, problem-solving skills, and technical competence‚Äîthrough prototypes, models, or practical solutions.

2Ô∏è‚É£ Improved critical thinking and problem-solving skills: Students will enhance their ability to analyze problems and develop feasible, impactful solutions.

3Ô∏è‚É£ Enhanced project management and teamwork skills: Students will gain experience in planning, budgeting, and managing resources within a collaborative environment.

4Ô∏è‚É£ Increased interdisciplinary knowledge and collaboration: Students will integrate knowledge from various disciplines to solve complex problems and work efficiently in diverse teams.

5Ô∏è‚É£ Cultivated a mindset of innovation and entrepreneurship: Students will learn to identify opportunities, take risks, and implement ideas with commercial or societal impact.

üìö LIST OF REPORTS:
- Any topic related to an innovative project.

English Language Lab.text:
üìò COURSE CODE: 100103P
üìó Subject: English Language Lab

üìö Perform any 10 Experiments:

Language Lab of English includes Listening Comprehension, Reading Comprehension, Speaking Skills: Phonetics, International Phonetic Alphabet Symbols (IPAS), Sounds: Vowels and Consonants, Pronunciation, Intonation, Stress and Rhythm, Just A Minute Technique (JAM), Communication: Verbal and Non-Verbal; Ethical Usage of Artificial Intelligence, Self-Introduction: Social, Academic and Professional; Interview: Online and Offline; Oral Presentation, Debate, Group Discussion, Group Activities, and Brainstorming

üìö Vocabulary Activities:

2Ô∏è‚É£ Reading Comprehension and Speed (Software)

3Ô∏è‚É£ Pronunciation: Learning and Test (Software)

1Ô∏è‚É£2Ô∏è‚É£ Anchoring and Addressing: an Assembly, a Meeting, a Seminar, a Party

Engineering Drawing Lab.text:
üìò COURSE CODE: 100104P
üìó Subject: Engineering Drawing Lab

üìö Perform any 10 Experiments:

1Ô∏è‚É£ Dimensioning methods, different types of lines, construction of different polygons, dividing lines and angles into parts, use of stencil.

2Ô∏è‚É£ Construction of Plane, Diagonal & Vernier Scales.

3Ô∏è‚É£ Construction of Ellipses, Parabolas, and Hyperbolas using the general method.

4Ô∏è‚É£ Construction of Cycloid, Epicycloid, Hypocycloid, and Involute of a circle.

5Ô∏è‚É£ Projection of Points and Lines inclined to both planes.

6Ô∏è‚É£ Projections of Planes (e.g., rectangular, triangular) in inclined positions.

7Ô∏è‚É£ Projection of Solids (Prisms, Pyramids, Cones, and Cylinders).

8Ô∏è‚É£ Drawing of Sections of Prisms, Cylinders, Pyramids, and Cones.

9Ô∏è‚É£ Development of Surfaces for Prisms, Pyramids, Cylinders, and Cones.

üîü Construction of Isometric Views of Lines, Planes, and Simple Solids.

1Ô∏è‚É£1Ô∏è‚É£ Introduction to CAD Software.

1Ô∏è‚É£2Ô∏è‚É£ Use of CAD software to draw basic geometric shapes, apply dimensions, and modify objects.

2415501 Hydraulics.text:
A) Course Code:
2415501 (T2415501 / P2415501 / S2415501)

B) Course Title:
Hydraulics

C) Pre-requisite Course(s):
None specified.

D) Rationale:
Civil, environmental, and transportation engineers must understand fluid flow behavior in pipes, channels, canals, notches, and weirs. This course provides foundational knowledge for solving real-world problems related to water seepage, discharge, and pressure. It supports advanced subjects like Irrigation, Water Resources Management, and Public Health Engineering.

E) Course Outcomes (COs):
After completing this course, students will be able to:

CO-1: Measure fluid pressure in different situations.

CO-2: Apply Bernoullis and Continuity Equations to fluid flow in closed conduits.

CO-3: Use Darcy Weisbach Equation to determine head loss in pipes.

CO-4: Design the most economical channel section using Chezys and Mannings formulae.

CO-5: Calculate discharge through notches and weirs.

F) Course Articulation Matrix (CAM):
COs	PO-1 (Basic Knowledge)	PO-2 (Problem Analysis)	PO-3 (Design Solutions)	PO-4 (Engineering Tools)	PO-5 (Sustainability)	PO-6 (Project Mgmt.)	PO-7 (Lifelong Learning)	PSO-1	PSO-2
CO-1	3 (High)	3	-	2	3	-	1	-	-
CO-2	3	-	-	2	2	-	2	-	-
CO-3	3	3	2	3	3	2	2	-	-
CO-4	3	2	2	2	2	2	1	-	-
CO-5	3	-	1	3	3	3	2	-	-
*(Legend: 3=High, 2=Medium, 1=Low, -=No mapping)*

G) Teaching & Learning Scheme:
Component	Hours/Week	Total Hours	Credits
Theory (CI)	3 (L) + 0 (T)	48	3
Practical (LI)	4	64	2
Term Work (TW) + Self-Learning (SL)	2	32	1
Total	9	144	6

H) Assessment Scheme:
Component	Marks
Theory (TA)	100
- Progressive Theory Assessment (PTA)	30
- End Theory Assessment (ETA)	70
Term Work & Self-Learning (TWA)	50
- Internal (40%)	20
- External (60%)	30
Lab Assessment (LA)	50
- Progressive Lab Assessment (PLA)	20
- End Lab Assessment (ELA)	30
Total	200

I) Course Curriculum (Theory - T2415501):
Unit 1: Introduction, Hydrostatic Pressure & Measurement
Fluid properties (viscosity, density, surface tension).

Pressure types (Atmospheric, Gauge, Absolute).

Measurement using Piezometer, U-tube Manometer.

Total Pressure & Centre of Pressure calculations.

Unit 2: Fluid Flow Parameters
Types of flow (Laminar/Turbulent, Steady/Unsteady).

Reynolds Number, Continuity Equation.

Bernoullis Theorem and applications.

Unit 3: Flow Through Pipes
Major & Minor Head Losses (friction, bends, expansions).

Hydraulic Gradient Line (HGL) & Total Energy Line (TEL).

Venturimeter, Orifice, Water Hammer effects.

Unit 4: Open Channel Flow
Chezys & Mannings formulae for channel design.

Most Economical Sections (Rectangular, Trapezoidal).

Specific Energy Diagram, Froudes Number.

Unit 5: Notches & Weirs
Discharge calculations (Rectangular, V-notch, Cipolletti weirs).

Coefficients (Cd, Cc, Cv) and their relationships.

J) Practical Experiments (P2415501):
Viscosity measurement using Viscometer.

Pressure measurement using Piezometer & Manometers.

Venturimeter for pipe discharge.

Orifice coefficients (Cc, Cv, Cd).

Discharge through V-notch & Rectangular weirs.

Reynolds Apparatus for flow type determination.

Friction factor & Minor Losses in pipes.

K) Term Work & Self-Learning (S2415501):
Assignments: Numerical problems on fluid mechanics.

Micro Projects:

Survey of canal structures (flow data, cross-sections).

Industry visit for pressure measurement devices.

Market survey of pipe materials (PVC, GI, HDPE).

Other Activities:

Demonstrations (videos, animations).

Field visits (dams, pumping stations).

L) Major Lab Equipment:
Venturimeter, Orifice, V-notch, U-tube Manometer, Reynolds Apparatus, Friction Factor Setup.

M) Books & Resources:
Modi & Seth  Hydraulics & Fluid Mechanics

Ramamrutham  Fluid Mechanics & Hydraulic Machines

NPTEL (IIT Lectures), TU Delft (Water Engineering Resources)

Final Notes:
60% weightage for external assessment (Term Work & Lab).

Emphasis on numerical problem-solving (each student gets unique values).

Industrial applications (pipeline design, irrigation systems).

2415502 RCC Structure.text:
A) Course Code:
2415502 (T2415502 / P2415502 / S2415502)

B) Course Title:
RCC Structure

C) Pre-requisite Courses:
Strength of Material

Theory of Structure

Concrete Technology

D) Rationale:
Infrastructure development is vital for economic growth. This course equips students to design safe, durable reinforced concrete structures (buildings, bridges, etc.) by:

Understanding design concepts and structural behavior.

Ensuring quality supervision and on-site execution.

Incorporating precast and pre-stressed concrete applications.

E) Course Outcomes (COs):
After completing this course, students will be able to:

CO-1: Design singly reinforced rectangular beams (Limit State Method/Working Stress Method).

CO-2: Design doubly reinforced rectangular beams (LSM).

CO-3: Design shear reinforcement for beams as per IS 456:2000.

CO-4: Design slabs (one-way, two-way, cantilever) under given loads.

CO-5: Design axially loaded short columns and isolated square footings (IS 456:2000).

F) Course Articulation Matrix (CAM):
COs	PO-1 (Knowledge)	PO-2 (Problem Analysis)	PO-3 (Design)	PO-4 (Tools)	PO-5 (Sustainability)	PO-6 (Mgmt.)	PO-7 (Learning)
CO-1	3 (High)	3	2	-	1	-	1
CO-2	3	3	2	-	1	-	1
CO-3	3	2	2	-	1	-	1
CO-4	3	3	2	-	1	-	1
CO-5	3	3	2	-	1	-	1
*(Legend: 3=High, 2=Medium, 1=Low, -=No mapping)*

G) Teaching & Learning Scheme:
Component	Hours/Week	Total Hours	Credits
Theory (CI)	3 (L) + 0 (T)	48	3
Practical (LI)	4	64	2
Term Work (TW) + Self-Learning (SL)	2	32	1
Total	9	144	6
H) Assessment Scheme:
Component	Marks
Theory (TA)	100
- Progressive Theory Assessment (PTA)	30
- End Theory Assessment (ETA)	70
Term Work & Self-Learning (TWA)	50
- Internal (40%)	20
- External (60%)	30
Lab Assessment (LA)	50
- Progressive Lab Assessment (PLA)	20
- End Lab Assessment (ELA)	30
Total	200
I) Theory Curriculum (T2415502):
Unit 1: Introduction to RCC & Design Methods
Stress-strain curves for concrete & steel.

Working Stress Method (WSM) vs. Limit State Method (LSM).

Analysis of singly reinforced beams (under-reinforced/balanced/over-reinforced).

Unit 2: Doubly Reinforced & Flanged Beams (LSM)
Need for doubly reinforced beams.

Analysis of T-beams/L-beams, effective flange width (IS 456:2000).

Unit 3: Shear, Bond & Development Length
Shear reinforcement design (IS 456).

Bond stress, development length, lapping of bars.

Unit 4: Slab Design (LSM)
One-way/cantilever/two-way slabs (IS Code method).

Checks for deflection, shear, development length.

Unit 5: Column & Footing Design (LSM)
Axially loaded short columns (square/rectangular/circular).

Isolated square footing design for flexure & shear.

J) Practical Experiments (P2415502):
Draw stress-strain diagrams for singly/doubly reinforced beams.

Design shear reinforcement for beams.

Design slabs (cantilever, one-way, two-way).

Design axially loaded columns.

Sketch column footing types.

K) Term Work & Activities (S2415502):
Assignments: Numerical problems on beam/slab/column design.

Micro Projects:

Study RCC design software (e.g., STAAD.Pro).

Site visit to audit formwork/reinforcement practices.

Seminars: Topics like earthquake-resistant design, FRP concrete.

L) Key Books & Resources:
Unnikrishna Pillai & Menon ‚Äì Reinforced Concrete Design (McGraw Hill).

IS 456:2000 ‚Äì Code for RCC design.

NPTEL Lectures (Online).

M) Lab Equipment:
Drawing boards, IS codebooks, design charts, software tools.

N) Exam Pattern (Theory):
Unit	Marks (ETA)
1	14
2	14
3	11
4	14
5	17
Total	70
(20% Rote, 22% Understanding, 28% Application)

Legend.Meaning: Progressive Theory Assessment in class room (includes class test, mid-term test and quiz using online/offline modes)
Progressive Laboratory Assessment (includes process and product assessment using rating Scales and rubrics)
